```lean4
import Mathlib

open Polynomial

-- Note: boosts domain of "isred" to all reals instead of just positive reals
abbrev putnam_2022_b3_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Assign to each positive real number a color, either red or blue. Let $D$ be the set of all distances $d>0$ such that there are two points of the same color at distance $d$ apart. Recolor the positive reals so that the numbers in $D$ are red and the numbers not in $D$ are blue. If we iterate this recoloring process, will we always end up with all the numbers red after a finite number of steps?
-/
theorem putnam_2022_b3
  (recolor : (ℝ → Prop) → (ℝ → Prop))
  (hrecolor : ∀ isred d, recolor isred d ↔ ∃ p q : ℝ, p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ p < q ∧ isred p = isred q ∧ q - p = d) :
  (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution :=
sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_2022_b3
  (recolor : (ℝ → Prop) → (ℝ → Prop))
  (hrecolor : ∀ isred d, recolor isred d ↔ ∃ p q : ℝ, p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ p < q ∧ isred p = isred q ∧ q - p = d) :
  (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution := by
  have step₁ : (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution := by
    have h1 := hrecolor true 0
    have h2 := hrecolor false 0
    have h3 := hrecolor true 1
    have h4 := hrecolor false 1
    have h5 := hrecolor true (-1)
    have h6 := hrecolor false (-1)
    have h7 := hrecolor (fun x => false) 0
    have h8 := hrecolor (fun x => true) 0
    have h9 := hrecolor (fun x => false) 1
    have h10 := hrecolor (fun x => true) 1
    have h11 := hrecolor (fun x => false) (-1)
    have h12 := hrecolor (fun x => true) (-1)
    simp at h1 h2 h3 h4 h5 h6 h7 h8 h9 h10 h11 h12
    <;> norm_num at * <;>
    (try {
      aesop
    }) <;>
    (try {
      simp_all [recolor, Function.iterate_fixed]
      <;> aesop
    }) <;>
    (try {
      aesop
    }) <;>
    (try {
      aesop
    })
    <;>
    aesop
  
  exact step₁
```

```lean4
theorem putnam_2022_b3
  (recolor : (ℝ → Prop) → (ℝ → Prop))
  (hrecolor : ∀ isred d, recolor isred d ↔ ∃ p q : ℝ, p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ p < q ∧ isred p = isred q ∧ q - p = d) :
  (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution := by
  have step₁ : (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution := by
    have h₁ := hrecolor false 0
    have h₂ := hrecolor false 1
    have h₃ := hrecolor true 0
    have h₄ := hrecolor true 1
    have h₅ := hrecolor (fun p => true) 0
    have h₆ := hrecolor (fun p => true) 1
    have h₇ := hrecolor (fun p => false) 0
    have h₈ := hrecolor (fun p => false) 1
    have h₉ := hrecolor (fun p => true) 2
    have h₁₀ := hrecolor (fun p => false) 2
    have h₁₁ := hrecolor (fun p => true) 1
    have h₁₂ := hrecolor (fun p => false) 1
    have h₁₃ := hrecolor (fun p => true) (1 / 2)
    have h₁₄ := hrecolor (fun p => false) (1 / 2)
    have h₁₅ := hrecolor (fun p => true) (3 / 2)
    have h₁₆ := hrecolor (fun p => false) (3 / 2)
    norm_num [recolor, Function.iterate_fixed] at *
    <;> aesop
  
  exact step₁
```

```lean4
import Mathlib

open Polynomial

-- Note: boosts domain of "isred" to all reals instead of just positive reals
abbrev putnam_2022_b3_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Assign to each positive real number a color, either red or blue. Let $D$ be the set of all distances $d>0$ such that there are two points of the same color at distance $d$ apart. Recolor the positive reals so that the numbers in $D$ are red and the numbers not in $D$ are blue. If we iterate this recoloring process, will we always end up with all the numbers red after a finite number of steps?
-/
theorem putnam_2022_b3
  (recolor : (ℝ → Prop) → (ℝ → Prop))
  (hrecolor : ∀ isred d, recolor isred d ↔ ∃ p q : ℝ, p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ p < q ∧ isred p = isred q ∧ q - p = d) :
  (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution :=
sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_2022_b3
  (recolor : (ℝ → Prop) → (ℝ → Prop))
  (hrecolor : ∀ isred d, recolor isred d ↔ ∃ p q : ℝ, p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ p < q ∧ isred p = isred q ∧ q - p = d) :
  (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution := by
  have step1 : (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution := by
    constructor
    -- Forward direction: Assume that for every initial coloring, there exists a finite number of iterations such that after that number of iterations, all positive real numbers are red.
    · intro h
      have h₁ := h (fun p => false)
      obtain ⟨k, hk⟩ := h₁
      have h₂ := hk 1 (by norm_num)
      have h₃ := hk (1 / 2) (by norm_num)
      have h₄ := hk 2 (by norm_num)
      have h₅ := hk (3 / 2) (by norm_num)
      simp [hrecolor, Function.iterate_fixed] at h₂ h₃ h₄ h₅
      <;> norm_num at * <;>
      (try { aesop }) <;>
      (try {
        have h₆ := hk 1 (by norm_num)
        simp_all [hrecolor, Function.iterate_fixed] <;> norm_num at * <;> aesop }) <;>
      (try {
        have h₆ := hk (1 / 2) (by norm_num)
        simp_all [hrecolor, Function.iterate_fixed] <;> norm_num at * <;> aesop })
    -- Reverse direction: Assume that after a finite number of iterations, all positive real numbers are red.
    · intro h
      have h₁ : ∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p) := by
        intro isred
        have h₂ : ∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p := by
          use 1
          intro p hp
          have h₃ := h
          simp_all [Function.iterate_fixed]
          <;> aesop
        exact h₂
      exact h₁
  
  exact step1
```

  (recolor : (ℝ → Prop) → (ℝ → Prop))

import Mathlib

open Polynomial

-- Note: boosts domain of "isred" to all reals instead of just positive reals
abbrev putnam_2022_b3_solution : Prop := sorry
-- True
/--
Assign to each positive real number a color, either red or blue. Let $D$ be the set of all distances $d>0$ such that there are two points of the same color at distance $d$ apart. Recolor the positive reals so that the numbers in $D$ are red and the numbers not in $D$ are blue. If we iterate this recoloring process, will we always end up with all the numbers red after a finite number of steps?
-/
theorem putnam_2022_b3
  (recolor : (ℝ → Prop) → (ℝ → Prop))
  (hrecolor : ∀ isred d, recolor isred d ↔ ∃ p q : ℝ, p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ p < q ∧ isred p = isred q ∧ q - p = d) :
  (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution :=
sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_2022_b3
  (recolor : (ℝ → Prop) → (ℝ → Prop))
  (hrecolor : ∀ isred d, recolor isred d ↔ ∃ p q : ℝ, p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ p < q ∧ isred p = isred q ∧ q - p = d) :
  (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution := by
  have step1 : (∀ isred, (∃ k, ∀ p > 0, (recolor^[k] isred) p)) ↔ putnam_2022_b3_solution := by
    have h₁ := hrecolor false 0
    have h₂ := hrecolor true 0
    have h₃ := hrecolor false 1
    have h₄ := hrecolor true 1
    have h₅ := hrecolor (fun p => true) 0
    have h₆ := hrecolor (fun p => false) 0
    have h₇ := hrecolor (fun p => true) 1
    have h₈ := hrecolor (fun p => false) 1
    have h₉ := hrecolor (fun p => true) 2
    have h₁₀ := hrecolor (fun p => false) 2
    have h₁₁ := hrecolor (fun p => true) (-1)
    have h₁₂ := hrecolor (fun p => false) (-1)
    have h₁₃ := hrecolor (fun p => true) (-2)
    have h₁₄ := hrecolor (fun p => false) (-2)
    norm_num [recolor, Function.iterate_fixed] at *
    <;> simp_all [exists_prop]
    <;> tauto
  
  exact step1
```
